Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: ASPiRe: Formative Assessment of Scientific Practices Research Practice Partnership

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Classroom assessment remains a significant challenge to most school districts that decide to implement the practice standards set forth by the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The Aurora Public School (APS) district is facing this challenge head-on by engaging in a research-practice partnership (RPP) with researchers at the University of Colorado at Boulder. Through this RPP entitled ASPiRe, the two partners will engage in a long-term collaboration that is intentionally organized to investigate problems of practice and generate evidence based solutions for improving district outcomes (through changes in the practices of teachers and students). The university-based team of faculty and graduate students will work with district instructional leaders, science content leaders, and science teachers to co-design formative assessments of scientific teaching practices in the NGSS and Colorado Academic Standards for all middle and high school teachers in the specific school district. The goal is to determine how formative assessment design and enactment can work to sensibly serve the many different participants and communities (district leadership, scientific practice teams, school-based teacher learning communities, and teachers) in ways that improve teaching and learning. This RAPID award capitalizes on the opportunity for the university to engage in a RPP with a whole school district that requested its assistance in using research-based evidence to improve formative assessment driven instructional practices for science teachers.

The project builds on evidence based lessons from prior NSF funding where results showed that long-term professional development linked to a learning progression can support teachers as they iteratively design, enact, and reflect upon formative assessments linked to NGSS practice standards. The project team will collaborate with, learn about, and contribute to efforts underway by APS to determine the best approach to integrate this intervention into science teaching and learning at the system level. Through a design-based implementation research (DBIR) approach, data will be collected at four levels of the district including classroom observations, videotaped meetings, artifacts, and interviews. An advisory board composed of nationally recognized education researchers will help guide the overall implementation of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Aspire RAPID project established a mutualistic collaboration between a large socioeconomically, culturally, and ethnically diverse school district and science education researchers at the University of Colorado Boulder focused on co-design and enactment of formative assessments linked to the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Working across multiple stakeholder groups, the Aspire RAPID project engaged science curriculum coordinators, K-12 science teachers, university-based science education faculty, and graduate students working across multiple sites to set new goals for science learning in the district and to design classroom assessments aligned with those goals.

The Aspire RAPID project supported and coordinated formative assessment co-design in whole-district professional development meetings in Year 1, as well as in school-based professional learning community meetings in Year 2. In addition, it supported district-wide design meetings in which teachers led the process of identifying three-dimensional priority standards that integrated disciplinary core ideas, scientific practices, and crosscutting concepts as exit statements to orient curriculum and assessment design in middle and high school.

A central problem of practice that emerged early in the course of the partnership was that teachers did not feel that formative assessment belonged to them, but that large-scale assessment pressures meant that assessment data could be used for their evaluations. Thus the Aspire partnership, in addition to supporting and coordinating formative assessment task design across these different stakeholder groups, also built trust and helped teachers recover the teaching and learning space in classrooms so that the process of formative assessment could improve the quality of instruction on a daily basis.

The project surfaced multiple dilemmas encountered by the science teachers as they engaged in designing and enacting formative assessments linked to the Next Generation Science Standards, including how to separate between instances of when students are engaging in three-dimensional learning, and when it is being assessed, as well as the heavy lift involved in asking teachers to design assessments for a type of instruction that they are only beginning to learn about themselves. The Aspire RAPID also helped to identify challenges in taking on all of the scientific practices as targets for co-designed formative assessments simultaneously, and led the Aspire Design team to focus more specifically on individual practices and specific task scaffolds to provide more specific and targeted supports for teachers. It also found that locating formative assessment co-design work was more effective when located in school-based, content-specific teacher learning communities, rather than conducted in whole-district, monthly professional development meetings.

Ultimately, the Aspire RAPID project set the groundwork for a long-term partnership between CU-Boulder researchers and the partner district which has resulted in a partnership that has endured beyond the life of the original project. Over time, the partnership has the potential to increase the quality of science instruction in this district, and also broaden participation in three-dimensional science learning for the diverse populations of students in the communities it serves. In addition, the Aspire RAPID project provided professional learning opportunities to the 60+ science teachers in this district, as well as mentored doctoral students into the professional practices of planning for and co-designing professional learning opportunities centered on formative assessment co-design.
